Message.Title: Yahoo and Mimvi ????
Message.Msg: Yahoo (NASDAQ:YHOO) CEO Marissa Mayer is expected to publicly announce her plans to turn her firm into a profitable entity this week. While the details of her internal memo (leaked by AllThingsD) did not reveal what she will announce, there is a good chance that it will involve one or more of the following things that could save Yahoo. 1. New Partnerships and an Entirely Revamped Search Engine Several months ago, Yahoo was rumored to be dumping Bing, Microsoft's (NASDAQ:MSFT) growing search engine, for Google (NASDAQ:GOOG). Nothing ever came of that rumor, so it seems unlikely that Yahoo will surprise the world by announcing that it will switch to Google tomorrow. Yahoo might, however, be inspired to drop Bing and other search engines altogether and do what it should have done all along: Develop a fresh engine from the ground up. In doing so, Yahoo would gain control of its company again. It would be able to dictate its search functionality and maximize its capability without having to rely on another party's technology. More importantly, it would give Yahoo the ability to sign massive, revenue-driving partnerships like the one that Google announced late last year. Google will pay Mozilla $300 million per year for three years to maintain its status as the default search engine in Firefox. By spending millions today, Google will make billions tomorrow. Yahoo could soon be in a position to do the same.

Message.Title: GOOD NEWS!!!
Message.Msg: Overnight, Eric Schmidt, Google‘s (GOOG) Executive Chairman, spoke in Tokyo at a launch event for a new Nexus tablet. Image by Charles Haynes via CrunchBase There are many articles this morning reporting on his comments tsk-tsking Apple (AAPL) for launching its own Map product instead of sticking with Google’s. What Yahoo! Should Do With Search Eric JacksonContributor Predicting The Strange Future Relationship of Yahoo!, Google, and Facebook Eric JacksonContributor Why Apple Maps and Siri Required Apple To Break Its 'No Beta' Rule Eric JacksonContributor Yahoo's Culture Problem? It's Already Fixed Eric JacksonContributor However, I can find no articles discussing how he also said Google is interested in replacing Microsoft‘s (MSFT) Bing as the search engine powering Yahoo! Yet, he did. At 1:48am New York time, Dow Jones ran the following headline on their wire service: “ Google Exec Chairman: Would Love to be Search Partner for Yahoo I followed up with Dow Jones reporter Kenneth Maxwell, who was at the event, to confirm that Schmidt did say this. His response to me: “ Yes, I can confirm, Eric Schmidt definitely said they’d be interested in working with Yahoo US. He also said nothing doing for the time being, but they would be interested. It was also mentioned to him that there is new management at Yahoo US with a Google connection. But he played it pretty straight…. He also said they had expressed this interest to Yahoo before on a number of occasions. Of course, Schmidt was involved in the discussions between Yahoo! and Google in late 2008 after the Microsoft buyout fell apart and before Carol Bartz approached Steve Ballmer to do a deal. Google and Yahoo strongly wanted a deal done, but the government said no. When Yahoo did the search deal with Microsoft in 2009, Yahoo Japan declined to participate. Instead they selected Google as their search partner. Several people who cover Yahoo have stated in very strong language that, although the search partnership with Microsoft has been a failure, there is no way that Yahoo could do an alternative deal with Google due to regulatory issues. I disagree with that view completely. A lot has changed since 2009. Yahoo!’s search share has dropped markedly. It also had to outsource all its back-end search technology (and talent, basically) to Microsoft. It simply isn’t the same situation now as it was then. And, if it was completely off the table, why would Eric Schmidt be musing about it aloud in Tokyo? Although he likes to muse aloud a lot, there would be no reason to mention it. This all comes as new Yahoo CEO, and former Google executive, Marissa Mayer prepares to give her state of the union address about Yahoo and the strategic direction that she’ll take it. Expect to hear a lot about her plans for reinvigorating search at Yahoo. Yahoo could cancel the Microsoft deal as early as next year according to the 2009 agreement. Would Marissa do a deal with Eric Schmidt? Both Yahoo and Google would certainly like to. 2 1 1 0 0 Overnight, Eric Schmidt, Google‘s (GOOG) Executive Chairman, spoke in Tokyo at a launch event for a new Nexus tablet. Image by Charles Haynes via CrunchBase There are many articles this morning reporting on his comments tsk-tsking Apple (AAPL) for launching its own Map product instead of sticking with Google’s. What Yahoo! Should Do With Search Eric JacksonContributor Predicting The Strange Future Relationship of Yahoo!, Google, and Facebook Eric JacksonContributor Why Apple Maps and Siri Required Apple To Break Its 'No Beta' Rule Eric JacksonContributor Yahoo's Culture Problem? It's Already Fixed Eric JacksonContributor However, I can find no articles discussing how he also said Google is interested in replacing Microsoft‘s (MSFT) Bing as the search engine powering Yahoo! Yet, he did. At 1:48am New York time, Dow Jones ran the following headline on their wire service: “ Google Exec Chairman: Would Love to be Search Partner for Yahoo I followed up with Dow Jones reporter Kenneth Maxwell, who was at the event, to confirm that Schmidt did say this. His response to me: “ Yes, I can confirm, Eric Schmidt definitely said they’d be interested in working with Yahoo US. He also said nothing doing for the time being, but they would be interested. It was also mentioned to him that there is new management at Yahoo US with a Google connection. But he played it pretty straight…. He also said they had expressed this interest to Yahoo before on a number of occasions. Of course, Schmidt was involved in the discussions between Yahoo! and Google in late 2008 after the Microsoft buyout fell apart and before Carol Bartz approached Steve Ballmer to do a deal. Google and Yahoo strongly wanted a deal done, but the government said no. When Yahoo did the search deal with Microsoft in 2009, Yahoo Japan declined to participate. Instead they selected Google as their search partner. Several people who cover Yahoo have stated in very strong language that, although the search partnership with Microsoft has been a failure, there is no way that Yahoo could do an alternative deal with Google due to regulatory issues. I disagree with that view completely. A lot has changed since 2009. Yahoo!’s search share has dropped markedly. It also had to outsource all its back-end search technology (and talent, basically) to Microsoft. It simply isn’t the same situation now as it was then. And, if it was completely off the table, why would Eric Schmidt be musing about it aloud in Tokyo? Although he likes to muse aloud a lot, there would be no reason to mention it. This all comes as new Yahoo CEO, and former Google executive, Marissa Mayer prepares to give her state of the union address about Yahoo and the strategic direction that she’ll take it. Expect to hear a lot about her plans for reinvigorating search at Yahoo. Yahoo could cancel the Microsoft deal as early as next year according to the 2009 agreement. Would Marissa do a deal with Eric Schmidt? Both Yahoo and Google would certainly like to.

Message.Title: Survey, what news could make Yahoo pop to $20?
Message.Msg: Everybody on earth knows that Yahoo is undervalued. After selling all the Alibaba and Yahoo Japan, Yahoo could own up to $18B cash, almost equal to its current market capital. Yahoo core itself is also creating around $1.3B cash every year. Everything is good but why Yahoo is still trading so low? I think the lack of confidence and huge floating size are the two major problems. IMO, Yahoo should buyback shares directly from those institutions who are willing to sell instead of buying from the open market. This could reduce the cost of both party and reduce the floating size quickly. I noticed that a few major shareholder have been selling hard on Yahoo. Why can't Yahoo talk to these institutions directly? To third point, how long do you want to wait for the buyback? Why not make it faster? Now that Yahoo has over $6B cash, it could easily buyback up to 400M floating shares from the institutions who don't want to hold Yahoo any more, let them go. After 400M buyback, Yahoo float could drop to 800M, Keep doing this after receiving more cash from Alibaba and Yahoo Japan(another $12B cash). We could easily reduce the float to 200M.

Topic.Title: On Oct 15, we will see $6B cash on Yahoo report.

Message.Msg: Before Alibaba goes public(maybe in 2013), it will buyback another 10% of its shares from Yahoo. If the evaluation for Alibaba on going public is $50B, 10% will be $5B, after tax Yahoo will receive about $3.3B cash. After this, Yahoo will hold $10B cash and will still hold 10% of Alibaba and 800M preferred shares. After Alibaba goes public, Yahoo could choose to sell its 10% shares and 800M preferred shares. Say Alibaba trades at $60B, Yahoo could get about $7B, after tax Yahoo will receive about $4.5B cash. After this, Yahoo will hold about $15B cash and still owns 35% of Yahoo Japan. After selling 35% of Yahoo Japan, Yahoo will get around $6B, after tax Yahoo will receive about $4B cash, after selling Yahoo Japan, Yahoo will hold about $19B cash.

Topic.Title: If YHOO is buying back serious shares why don't they defend $16? They should buy....

Message.Msg: There is a limit on how, when, at what price and how many shares Yahoo can buy back. For instance Yahoo can only buy at last trading price or lower and only 25% of the average volume. Those limits are set to minimize market impact of a buyback and prevent market manipulation. Those limits also cause large buybacks to take years in completion. Also Yahoo can only start buying after a buyback has been board approved, publicly announced and filed with the SEC.

Topic.Title: If YHOO is buying back serious shares why don't they defend $16? They should buy....

Topic.Title: Dividend

Message.Msg: What? Uhmmm, a dividend is a steady guaranteed yield on a position you hold. The stock price will always fluctuate (up or down) normally with the market volatility. That concept you have is the same that many other people have. That concept is true for a company that pays out a "Special Dividend" which is usually a one time large divi pay out given for a special reason. In that case, "YES", the stock price drops that dollar amount, but in the case of a steady dividend then "NO". For example: Today YHOO trades at $16 bucks. Tomorrow it pays out the dividend which for this purpose we will say is $.08 per share. If you hold a position of 1000 shares, then you receive $80 dollars. The stock for the next trading days will be range bound trading wherever it will trade based on market conditions, earnings, news, or whatever.... Those $.08 cents are not going to affect anything among the billion shares outstanding and millions of shareholders of YHOO. The $80.00 are guaranteed in my pocket each quarter while the stock price will move up and down until I decide to sell.

Topic.Title: Dividend

Message.Msg: More Clarification!! If the asset sold was not on the books, but at the $1 Million paid years ago and 1/2 of it was sold at a multiples magnitude type profit, then buying back shares should not affect a price that has not reflected the appreciated asset to date, but the per share price should go up with a reduced number of shares being outstanding. Please also note that it is planned that about $650 million(about equal to 1/2 of the original investment years ago) is being retained to operate with or purchase with so the original booked assets remain on the books, again supporting no drop in the share price, but yes an increase in share price due to the lesser number of shares outstanding. A special divedend straight to the shareholders should also not affect the price on the surface considering the investment profit has not been on the books until right now, but it is not as good for the company or long term shareholders looking for the have increased share prices over time for it takes away the use of the assets improved evaluation in improving the operations of the company.
